title: Psalms Chapter 143 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 143 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 143 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 143.

questions.question: Who is the psalmist of Psalms Chapter 143?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: The psalm is explicitly attributed to David in Psalms 143:1.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:2, what is said about judgment with God's servant?
options: No man living shall be justified
questions.correctAnswer: No man living shall be justified
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:2 states that in God's sight no man living shall be justified.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:3, what has the enemy done to the psalmist's soul?
questions.correctAnswer: Persecuted it
questions.explanation: The verse clearly says the enemy has persecuted the psalmist's soul.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:6, the psalmist's soul thirsts after God like what?
questions.correctAnswer: A thirsty land
questions.explanation: The psalmist compares his soul's thirst for God to a thirsty land in Psalms 143:6.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do quickly in Psalms 143:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Hear me speedily
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:7 records the psalmist asking God to hear him quickly.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 143:9 says the psalmist flees to God to hide from his enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly mentions fleeing to God to hide from enemies.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:10, why does the psalmist ask God to teach him?
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is his God
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks for instruction because God is his God, as stated in Psalms 143:10.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:11, for whose sake does the psalmist ask God to quicken him?
questions.correctAnswer: For God's name's sake
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to quicken him for the sake of God's name in Psalms 143:11.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 143:4: 'Therefore is my spirit ______ within me; my heart within me is desolate.'
questions.correctAnswer: overwhelmed
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:4 says that the spirit is overwhelmed within the psalmist.

questions.question: Which action does the psalmist do in Psalms 143:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Meditates on God's works
questions.explanation: The psalmist remembers and meditates on God's works as stated in Psalms 143:5.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 143:12 says the psalmist is God's servant.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares himself as God's servant in Psalms 143:12.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to cause him to hear in the morning in Psalms 143:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Lovingkindness
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks to hear God's lovingkindness in the morning, as found in Psalms 143:8.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:11, what does the psalmist want God to bring his soul out of?
questions.correctAnswer: Trouble
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to bring his soul out of trouble in Psalms 143:11.

questions.question: What does the psalmist stretch forth unto God in Psalms 143:6?
questions.correctAnswer: His hands
questions.explanation: The psalmist stretches forth his hands unto God in Psalms 143:6.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 143:7 warns that if God hides His face, the psalmist will be like those who go down into the pit.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalmist expresses fear of being like those who go down into the pit if God hides His face, in Psalms 143:7.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 143 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 143 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by trials and asks for guidance on prayer. Based on Psalms 143, how should they approach God in prayer?
options: With faithfulness and righteousness, seeking God’s ear
By demanding immediate answers without humility
Ignoring God’s righteousness and focusing on self
Praying only in times of joy and not in distress
questions.correctAnswer: With faithfulness and righteousness, seeking God’s ear
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:1 teaches us to pray with faithfulness and righteousness, asking God to hear our supplications. This shows the importance of humble, faithful prayer even in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 143:2 teach us about humility in the presence of God?
options: No living man is justified before God, so we must not enter into judgment with Him
We can boast about our righteousness before God
God always blames us for our troubles
Judgment is unnecessary because we are all perfect
questions.correctAnswer: No living man is justified before God, so we must not enter into judgment with Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:2 says that no living man is justified in God’s sight, emphasizing humility and the need to rely on His mercy rather than our own righteousness.

questions.question: When feeling persecuted and overwhelmed, what biblical truth from Psalms 143 can help a believer persevere?
options: God is aware of our soul’s suffering and we can seek His help
We should hide our feelings and pretend everything is fine
Persecution means God has abandoned us
We must only rely on ourselves to overcome troubles
questions.correctAnswer: God is aware of our soul’s suffering and we can seek His help
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:3-4 describes persecution and overwhelming spirit, but the psalmist turns to God, teaching us to seek God’s aid in hardship.

questions.question: How does meditating on God’s works, as seen in Psalms 143:5, strengthen a believer’s faith during difficult times?
options: It reminds us of God’s faithfulness and power, encouraging trust
It distracts us from our problems without real benefit
It makes us focus on past mistakes instead of God’s goodness
It causes discouragement by remembering old troubles
questions.correctAnswer: It reminds us of God’s faithfulness and power, encouraging trust
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:5 shows the psalmist reflecting on God’s works, which encourages faith and hope despite current trials.

questions.question: What does Psalms 143:6 teach about spiritual longing and devotion?
options: A believer’s soul should thirst for God like a thirsty land longs for water
Spiritual thirst is unimportant in Christian life
Only physical needs matter to God
Spiritual longing should be suppressed to focus on daily tasks
questions.correctAnswer: A believer’s soul should thirst for God like a thirsty land longs for water
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:6 uses the metaphor of a thirsty land to show deep spiritual desire for God, which is vital for Christian devotion.

questions.question: How can a believer rely on God’s lovingkindness each morning, according to Psalms 143?
options: By trusting God daily and asking Him to guide our path
By ignoring God’s guidance and making our own plans
By hoping for luck instead of God’s mercy
By relying solely on human wisdom without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God daily and asking Him to guide our path
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:8 encourages believers to seek God’s lovingkindness each morning and trust in Him to know the right way to walk.

questions.question: A believer is fleeing from spiritual enemies. How does Psalms 143 guide them in seeking refuge?
options: Flee to the LORD and hide in Him for safety
Try to face enemies alone without God’s help
Ignore the threats and hope they disappear
Rely on worldly power instead of God
questions.correctAnswer: Flee to the LORD and hide in Him for safety
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:9 shows the psalmist fleeing to God for protection, teaching believers to seek refuge in the Lord during trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 143:10 encourage believers to grow in obedience and spiritual direction?
options: By asking God to teach His will and lead into uprightness
By following personal desires without seeking God
By ignoring God’s Spirit and relying on self-righteousness
By refusing to learn from God’s Word
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God to teach His will and lead into uprightness
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:10 teaches the importance of seeking God’s instruction and guidance to live uprightly and obey His will.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance and hope can a believer learn from Psalms 143:11?
options: God can revive our souls and rescue us from trouble for His name’s sake
We must rely solely on our strength
Troubles are always punishment and never relief is possible
God is indifferent to our suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God can revive our souls and rescue us from trouble for His name’s sake
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:11 shows the psalmist asking God to quicken his soul and deliver him, reminding believers of God’s power to restore and save.

questions.question: How does Psalms 143 instruct believers to deal with enemies and affliction in a way that honors God?
options: By asking God, in His mercy, to remove those who afflict us because we serve Him
By seeking revenge personally without God’s guidance
By ignoring enemies and refusing to pray about them
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God, in His mercy, to remove those who afflict us because we serve Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:12 teaches believers to seek God’s mercy to cut off enemies and afflictors, recognizing our relationship as His servants.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 143, a believer’s spirit can fail and they should ask God to hear them speedily.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:7 shows the psalmist’s spirit failing and his urgent plea for God to hear him quickly, teaching believers to seek God earnestly in weakness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 143 teaches that we should trust in ourselves rather than lifting our souls to God for guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:8 says the psalmist lifts his soul to God and trusts Him to cause him to know the way to walk, emphasizing reliance on God rather than self.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 143:6 compares the soul’s thirst for God to a ________.
questions.correctAnswer: thirsty land
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:6 uses the simile of a thirsty land longing for water to express the soul’s deep desire for God.

questions.question: A believer reflecting on Psalms 143 wants to understand the importance of God’s righteousness. How does this chapter connect righteousness with God’s response to prayer?
options: God answers prayers in His righteousness and faithfulness
Righteousness is irrelevant to God’s hearing of prayer
Only human righteousness matters for prayer to be answered
God answers without regard to righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: God answers prayers in His righteousness and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:1 emphasizes God answering prayers in His faithfulness and righteousness, showing these attributes are key to His response.

questions.question: How does Psalms 143 encourage believers to maintain integrity and uprightness in daily life?
options: By asking God to lead us into the land of uprightness
By ignoring God’s commands and doing what we please
By pretending to be upright only in public
By relying on others to keep us upright
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God to lead us into the land of uprightness
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:10 shows the psalmist asking God to lead him into uprightness, teaching believers to seek God’s guidance for integrity.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 143 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 143.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:2, why does the psalmist say that no man living can be justified in God's sight?
options: Because men do not keep the law perfectly
Because men are judged by their works
questions.correctAnswer: Because all men are sinners
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:2 states, 'for in thy sight shall no man living be justified,' indicating the universal sinful state of humanity before God.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Psalms 143:3 when the psalmist describes dwelling "in darkness, as those that have been long dead"?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The phrase 'as those that have been long dead' in Psalms 143:3 compares the psalmist's condition to the dead using 'as,' which is a simile.

questions.question: Psalms 143:5 mentions the psalmist meditating on God’s works. This reflects which Old Testament theme?
options: The importance of remembering God's mighty acts
questions.correctAnswer: The importance of remembering God's mighty acts
questions.explanation: In Psalms 143:5, the psalmist recalls 'the days of old' and meditates on God's works, echoing the biblical theme of recalling God's past deeds as encouragement (cf. Deuteronomy 6:12).

questions.question: The expression "my soul thirsteth after thee, as a thirsty land" in Psalms 143:6 is an example of which poetic technique?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The psalmist uses 'as' to compare the soul's longing to a thirsty land, which is a simile (Psalms 143:6).

questions.question: What is the significance of the word 'Selah' found in Psalms 143:6?
options: It indicates a pause for contemplation
It is a call to worship
It marks the end of the psalm
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a pause for contemplation
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is understood as a liturgical or musical term indicating a pause or reflection, prompting the listener to meditate on the preceding words (Psalms 143:6).

questions.question: In Psalms 143:7, the psalmist pleads, "hide not thy face from me," a phrase that also appears in which other Old Testament book emphasizing God's presence?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah
questions.explanation: The plea for God not to 'hide His face' is a recurring motif in Isaiah (e.g., Isaiah 54:8), signifying the desire for God's presence and favor (Psalms 143:7).

questions.question: The request in Psalms 143:8 to 'know the way wherein I should walk' is thematically connected to which New Testament teaching?
options: Jesus as the Way, the Truth, and the Life
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus as the Way, the Truth, and the Life
questions.explanation: The psalmist’s desire for guidance (Psalms 143:8) prefigures Jesus’ declaration in John 14:6 that He is the Way, highlighting the theme of divine guidance.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:9, the psalmist flees to God to hide from enemies. This is an example of which ancient Near Eastern cultural motif?
options: God as a fortress and refuge
questions.correctAnswer: God as a fortress and refuge
questions.explanation: The imagery of seeking shelter in God aligns with the ancient Near Eastern motif of God as a protective fortress (Psalms 143:9).

questions.question: The petition in Psalms 143:10 to be taught God’s will and led by His Spirit reflects which theological concept prominent in biblical wisdom literature?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine guidance through the Spirit
questions.explanation: Psalms 143:10 highlights the importance of the Spirit’s guidance, a key theme in wisdom literature emphasizing God’s direction in human life.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:11, the phrase 'Quicken me, O LORD' uses the Hebrew term 'chayah.' What is the significance of this term in biblical theology?
options: It signifies restoration of life and vitality
It refers to physical healing exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies restoration of life and vitality
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'chayah' means 'to live' or 'to make alive,' emphasizing restoration and renewal as in Psalms 143:11.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 143 is primarily a song of thanksgiving for past victories.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 143 is a penitential and supplicatory psalm expressing distress and seeking deliverance rather than thanksgiving (Psalms 143:1-12).

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 143:12 reflects the covenant relationship between God and the psalmist?
options: The psalmist's identity as God's servant
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist's identity as God's servant
questions.explanation: In Psalms 143:12, the psalmist acknowledges being God's servant, affirming the covenant relationship and dependence on divine mercy.

questions.question: The structure of Psalms 143 reveals a chiastic pattern focusing on which central request?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine guidance and deliverance
questions.explanation: The psalm uses a chiastic literary structure centering around the plea for guidance and deliverance (Psalms 143:8-11).

questions.question: How does Psalms 143 relate typologically to the New Testament concept of Jesus as the intercessor?
options: David’s prayer foreshadows Christ’s intercession for sinners
It focuses solely on temple rituals
questions.correctAnswer: David’s prayer foreshadows Christ’s intercession for sinners
questions.explanation: David’s plea for mercy and deliverance in Psalms 143 anticipates Christ’s role as mediator interceding for humanity (cf. Romans 8:34).

questions.question: The phrase "my heart within me is desolate" in Psalms 143:4 uses Hebrew imagery to express what kind of emotional state?
questions.correctAnswer: Deep spiritual distress and loneliness
questions.explanation: The Hebrew imagery in Psalms 143:4 conveys profound inner desolation and emotional turmoil.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 143 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 143 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:1, what two attributes of God does the psalmist appeal to for answering his prayer?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and righteousness
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to answer in His faithfulness and righteousness (Psalms 143:1). This aligns with God's character in Exodus 34:6-7, Lamentations 3:22-23, Romans 3:25-26, and 2 Timothy 2:13 showing His faithful and righteous nature.

questions.question: What theological truth about human justification before God is stated in Psalms 143:2?
options: No one living is justified in God's sight
God justifies all who fear Him
questions.correctAnswer: No one living is justified in God's sight
questions.explanation: Verse 2 declares that no man living will be justified before God’s sight, highlighting human sinfulness and need for divine grace. This is consistent with Romans 3:10, Ecclesiastes 7:20, Isaiah 64:6, and Galatians 2:16 which affirm humanity's universal sinfulness and inability to justify themselves.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:3, how does the psalmist describe the effect of his enemy's persecution?
options: His soul is persecuted and he dwells in darkness
He is physically harmed but remains hopeful
He finds refuge among his allies
questions.correctAnswer: His soul is persecuted and he dwells in darkness
questions.explanation: The psalmist says the enemy has persecuted his soul, smitten him down, and made him dwell in darkness like the dead (143:3). This metaphor reflects deep anguish and alienation from life, similar to Job 10:21-22, Lamentations 3:6, Psalm 88:6, and Isaiah 38:10.

questions.question: What is the emotional state of the psalmist as expressed in Psalms 143:4?
options: His spirit is overwhelmed and his heart desolate
He is joyful and full of praise
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit is overwhelmed and his heart desolate
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states that the psalmist’s spirit is overwhelmed and his heart desolate, expressing deep despair. This resonates with David’s laments in Psalm 42:11, Psalm 6:6-7, Jeremiah 20:9, and Jonah 2:7.

questions.question: What does the psalmist meditate on according to Psalms 143:5?
options: All God's works and the work of His hands
questions.correctAnswer: All God's works and the work of His hands
questions.explanation: Verse 5 reveals that the psalmist remembers the days of old and meditates on all God's works and the work of His hands. This meditation on God's creative and redemptive acts is echoed in Psalm 77:11-12, Psalm 8:3-4, Romans 1:20, and Colossians 1:16.

questions.question: Psalms 143:6 uses a simile to describe the psalmist's soul. What is it compared to?
questions.correctAnswer: A thirsty land
questions.explanation: The psalmist says his soul thirsts after God as a thirsty land thirsts for water (143:6). This analogy illustrates deep spiritual longing, consistent with Isaiah 55:1, John 4:13-14, Psalm 42:1-2, and Revelation 21:6.

questions.question: What urgent request does the psalmist make to God in Psalms 143:7?
options: Hear me speedily and hide not Your face
Give me strength to defeat my enemies
Send an angel to protect me
questions.correctAnswer: Hear me speedily and hide not Your face
questions.explanation: In verse 7, the psalmist implores God to hear him quickly and not to hide His face, lest he perish like those who go down to the pit. This plea for God’s immediate presence is similar to Psalm 31:16, Isaiah 64:7, Lamentations 3:57, and Hebrews 4:16.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:8, why does the psalmist want to hear God’s lovingkindness in the morning?
options: Because he trusts in God and wants to know the way to walk
Because he wants to receive material blessings
Because he desires to judge his enemies
Because he wants to be healed physically
questions.correctAnswer: Because he trusts in God and wants to know the way to walk
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states the psalmist desires to hear God's lovingkindness in the morning because he trusts in God and wants to know the way he should walk. This reflects a trust and guidance motif seen in Psalm 25:4-5, Proverbs 3:5-6, Isaiah 30:21, and John 14:6.

questions.question: What is the psalmist’s response to his enemies as expressed in Psalms 143:9?
options: He flees unto the LORD to hide
He ignores them and walks away
questions.correctAnswer: He flees unto the LORD to hide
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says the psalmist asks God to deliver him from enemies because he flees to God to hide. This reflects trust in God’s protection, similar to Psalm 59:1, Psalm 27:1-5, Psalm 91:1-2, and 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: In Psalms 143:10, what does the psalmist ask God to teach him?
options: To gain wisdom in worldly affairs
questions.correctAnswer: To do God's will
questions.explanation: The psalmist requests instruction in doing God's will, acknowledging God as his God and the goodness of His spirit (143:10). This plea aligns with Psalm 25:4-5, John 6:38, Romans 12:2, and Ephesians 5:17 about walking in God's will.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to lead him into in Psalms 143:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of uprightness
questions.explanation: Verse 10 requests God to lead the psalmist into the land of uprightness, symbolizing a life of righteousness and moral integrity. This is consistent with Psalm 23:3, Proverbs 4:18, Isaiah 35:8, and Matthew 5:6.

questions.question: According to Psalms 143:11, why does the psalmist ask God to quicken him?
options: For God's name's sake and righteousness' sake
questions.correctAnswer: For God's name's sake and righteousness' sake
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks to be quickened for God's name's and righteousness' sake (143:11), emphasizing God's glory and justice as reasons for deliverance. This reflects themes in Ezekiel 36:22-23, Romans 3:25-26, Psalm 106:8, and 2 Thessalonians 1:11.

questions.question: What request does the psalmist make concerning his enemies in Psalms 143:12?
options: Cut off mine enemies and destroy those who afflict my soul
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off mine enemies and destroy those who afflict my soul
questions.explanation: Verse 12 petitions God’s mercy to cut off enemies and destroy those afflicting the psalmist’s soul, reflecting a plea for divine justice. This is consistent with Psalm 109:6, Psalm 68:1, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 6:10 where God is invoked to judge oppressors.

questions.question: How does the psalmist identify himself in relation to God in Psalms 143:12?
questions.correctAnswer: I am your servant
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls himself God's servant (143:12), indicating submission and covenant relationship. This self-identification aligns with Psalm 116:16, Isaiah 42:1, Luke 1:38, and Romans 1:1.

questions.question: What is the overall theological theme of Psalms 143 based on the entire chapter?
options: A prayer for deliverance grounded in God's righteousness and mercy
A celebration of human strength and wisdom
A description of God’s judgment on nations
A prophetic vision of the end times
questions.correctAnswer: A prayer for deliverance grounded in God's righteousness and mercy
questions.explanation: The entire Psalm is a heartfelt plea for God’s deliverance, emphasizing His righteousness, mercy, and faithfulness (Psalms 143:1-12). This theme is echoed in Psalms 34:17-18, Isaiah 51:6-8, Romans 10:12-13, and Hebrews 4:16.
